title: 104_hr2166
content: The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" establishes a minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations under Subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This Act aims to ensure fairness and equity in tax liabilities for these entities. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain corporations based on their business activities and foreign ownership. The taxable income must meet a certain percentage of gross receipts, and the Act applies to corporations with substantial foreign-related transactions. There is an exception if an alternative method is approved by the Secretary. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain corporations with substantial foreign-related transactions. An exception exists if a qualified section 482 agreement is in effect with the Secretary for specific business activities. The Secretary may enter into a qualified section 482 agreement for transactions with related parties in specific business activities of a corporation to reflect taxable income. The agreement can have retroactive effects for prior taxable years if deemed necessary. If a corporation's activities cannot be categorized, an exception applies. The corporation may be subject to a minimum tax of 35 percent on gross receipts from property sales if activities cannot be categorized. The section may be waived in cases of casualty or disaster, and foreign taxes are not considered in taxable income calculations. The Secretary may waive the application of the minimum tax in cases of casualty or disaster if deemed inequitable. Foreign taxes are not included in taxable income calculations. The Secretary prescribes applicable profit percentages for different business activities based on domestic corporations' average earnings rates. The earnings rate of domestic corporations for different business activities is determined based on the ratio of adjusted book income to gross receipts. The term 'adjusted book income' excludes certain taxes imposed by the US, US possessions, or foreign countries. Definitions for terms like '25-percent foreign-owned' are provided in section 6038A(c). The tax code defines terms like '25-percent foreign-owned' and 'related party'. It also outlines rules for substantial foreign-related person transactions and categorizing business activities based on Standard Industrial Classification Codes. The tax code categorizes business activities based on Standard Industrial Classification Codes, allowing for aggregation of classifications and alternative classification systems when appropriate. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts for subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. Effective Date: The amendments for minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
